P: class of problems solvable in polynomial time

NP: class of decision problems solvable in nondeterministic polynomial time. Nondeterministic here means: we can make a guess (instead of considering all possibilities) and this guess is always good (if 'yes' answer exists). In other words: if the answer is 'yes' then given a solution we can check it in polynomial time
NP-hard: problem X <- NP-hard if every problem from NP can be reduced to X. This means: X is at least as hard as every problem in NP
NP-complete: class of problems both in NP and NP-hard
If A reduces to B then this means B is at least as hard as A
Reduction from problem A to B === change input A to equivalent input B (equivalent means does not change result)

How to prove that X is NP-hard? First show that X is NP. Then take any Y from NP-hard problems and reduce Y to X. Which tells us X is at least as hard as Y and Y is NP-hard so X is also NP-hard. Example: 3-SAT is NP-hard, convert any 3-SAT formula to Mario's map/board => playing Mario is NP-hard
